DOC.brief_summary: The Northwestern University Two-Generation Child and Family Outcomes Study (NU2Gen) of the Community Action Project of Tulsa County's (CAP Tulsa's) CareerAdvance® program examine the effects of CareerAdvance® on child outcomes (e.g., child academic achievement and behavior).
DOC.brief_title: The Northwestern University Two-Generation Child and Family Outcomes Study of CAP Tulsa's CareerAdvance® Program
DOC.detailed_description: CAP Tulsa's Health Profession Opportunity Grant (HPOG II) involves a randomized control trial of CareerAdvance®'s impact on approximately 1,000 parents in the Tulsa, Oklahoma area. Through HPOG II, CAP Tulsa will participate in a national evaluation to measure the effects of program participation on adult educational and employment outcomes. The Northwestern University research team's subcontract through CAP Tulsa, as part of the HPOG II grant, involves a supplementary effectiveness study focusing on child outcomes. The study will employ: (1) primary data based on a brief parent survey at the time of program application; (2) secondary data on parents' progress in the CareerAdvance® program and other related community programs and employers (e.g., Madison Strategies Group's WorkAdvance Tulsa); and (3) child-level public elementary administrative data from local public school districts in Tulsa County, Oklahoma. Northwestern's study will be conducted in tandem with the national evaluation. Findings will have implications for how two-generation educational programs influence child development and will offer guidance on how to integrate this approach into Head Start and other school-based educational programming.
DOC.criteria: Applicants to CAP Tulsa's CareerAdvance® program under the HPOG II evaluation study, including participants who are randomly assigned not to participate in CareerAdvance® by the HPOG II evaluation study. Not proficient in English
